item.title: Apple Has Finally Stuck A Dagger Into SMS. I Love It.
item.description: Apple Has Finally Stuck A Dagger Into SMS. I Love It. http://tcrn.ch/lUCbhX by @parislemon
item.content:encoded: Apple Has Finally Stuck A Dagger Into SMS. I Love It. http://tcrn.ch/lUCbhX by @parislemon Now that the WWDC keynote is over and I've had a little bit of time to reflect, I've been thinking about what excited me the most from today's announcements. The list is long, no doubt. But I think I'm going to have to go with something that surprised me — while at the same time making me look smarter than perhaps I really am. (Again, just perhaps.) iMessages. As one of the core new features highlighted today in iOS 5, iMessages has one purpose: to kill SMS. That is, traditional carrier-controlled text messages. iMessages will do this by replacing SMS with a service that Apple is in control of across all of their iOS devices. And here's the real death blow: iMessages will be completely free. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: She texted. We kicked her out. : Blog : Austin : Alamo Drafthouse Cinema
item.description: Great Drafthouse PSA about texting in theaters! http://bit.ly/miAcrd #funny
item.content:encoded: Great Drafthouse PSA about texting in theaters! http://bit.ly/miAcrd #funny As many of you know, I really can't abide people who talk during a movie. A couple of years ago I was accosted in the Village parking lot by a patron who was warned for talking in a movie. I've nearly come to blows more than a few times over the years with rude customers over the same issue. When we adopted our strict no talking policy back in 1997 we knew we were going to alienate some of our patrons. That was the plan. If you can't change your behavior and be quiet (or unilluminated) during a movie, then we don't want you at our venue. Follow our rules, or get the hell out and don't come back until you can. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: drafthouse.com

item.title: Watch Out Facebook Connect, Apple Pushes Twitter Sign-Ins In iOS 5
item.description: Watch Out Facebook Connect, Apple Pushes Twitter Sign-Ins http://tcrn.ch/lVbroA by @leenarao
item.content:encoded: Watch Out Facebook Connect, Apple Pushes Twitter Sign-Ins http://tcrn.ch/lVbroA by @leenarao Apple just announced a fairly in-depth 'Twitterification' of the newest version of its mobile OS, iOS 5 (which we reported last week to be taking place). As Apple says during the WWDC keynote today, there are 1 billion Tweets per week now and we want to make it even easier for all our customers to use Twitter in our iOS products. Now Apple provides a single sign-on for Twitter use on the phone, and with any app you download, it will just ask you for Twitter credential permission. There's no need to re login. Apple has taken it a step further to integrate Twitter into many of its own features and applications like camera and photos. You can also Tweet articles and content directly from Safari, Maps, videos from YouTube, etc and add location as well. And Twitter photos and @usernames can be autopulled into the phone's contacts. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

item.title: Mac OS X Lion: Coming In July For $29 (And You Won’t Be Able To Buy It On A Disc)
item.description: Mac OS X Lion: Coming In July For $29 (And You Won't Be Able To Buy It On A Disc) http://tcrn.ch/k5b519 by @jasonkincaid
item.content:encoded: Mac OS X Lion: Coming In July For $29 (And You Won't Be Able To Buy It On A Disc) http://tcrn.ch/k5b519 by @jasonkincaid Today during the WWDC keynote at the Moscone Center in San Francisco, Apple spent a good 40 minutes walking through the latest features of OS X, the powerful operating system that runs on its laptop and desktop machines. The latest version of OS X, called Lion, has been in testing with developers for months now, and now we have a better idea of when customers will be able to get their hands on it: it's coming in July, and it's going to be a mere $29. And there's another significant piece of news: you won't be able to purchase Lion in retail stores on a physical optical disc, as it will only be available as a download via the Mac App Store. The download will weigh in at around 4 gigabytes, or around the size of a movie. The developer preview will be available today. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com

Mu Sigma in a press statement says it currently employs some 1,200 analysts (and growing), mostly based in India, in an effort to build the world's Link - Trackbacks

item.title: Live From Apple’s WWDC 2011 Keynote
item.description: Live From Apple's WWDC 2011 Keynote http://tcrn.ch/m32g2m by @grg
item.content:encoded: Live From Apple's WWDC 2011 Keynote http://tcrn.ch/m32g2m by @grg We're live in not-so-sunny San Francisco, where Apple is hosting their annual Worldwide Developer Conference — and, more directly important to the masses of Apple fans around the world, the WWDC Keynote. We already know some of what Apple's announcing: OS X Lion, iOS 5, and a new, mostly-mysterious product called iCloud. From what we're seeing, though, they've got at least one secret up their sleeve. Join us after the jump for all of our up-to-the-second updates. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: techcrunch.com
